newsitem.title: JAPAN: Idemitsu says sees high crude price until end-1996.
newsitem.headline: Idemitsu says sees high crude price until end-1996.

text.p: Crude oil prices are likely to stay at high levels for the rest of 1996, reflecting firm global demand and low oil product inventories in North America and Europe, an official with a Japanese refiner said on Tuesday.
"Crude prices are likely to stay firm for the rest of this year at least," Idemitsu Kosan Co Ltd senior managing director Yasuyuki Yoshida told reporters.
The delay in the implementation of an oil-for-food deal between the United Nations and Iraq, as well as instability in the Middle East, would also keep prices at high levels, Yoshida said.
The price of Dubai crude, the benchmark in Asian markets, averaged $20.4 per barrel in September. This compares with an average $16.6 in January this year and $15.5 in September 1995.

Yoshida said the resumption of Iraq's crude exports under its deal with the U.N. could trigger a downward correction in prices. Iraqi exports are not expected to resume until the first quarter of 1997 at the earliest, he said.

The oil-for-food accord would allow oil sales of $2 billion every six months to provide humanitarian relief for the Iraqi people suffering under sanctions imposed by the U.N. after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990.
